notesStmt.note: I.B. = John Baker; I.H. = John Hooper.

"A briefe and cleare confession of the Christian faith" is in fact a translation, by John Hooper, of Jean Garnier: Briefve et claire confession de la foy chrestienne, contenant cent articles, selon l'ordre du symbole des apostres. Another translation, by Nicholas Malby, was published in 1562 with title: A briefe and plaine confession of the Christian faithe.
"A briefe and cleare confession of the Christian fayth" has separate title page (leaf Bb1r); register is continuous.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

For if this Creede, commonly called the Creede of the ApoÅ¿tles, Å¿hall onely be Å¿ayde without booke, and rehearÅ¿ed of the people, without the meaning of it in more words: then they can not take Å¿uch coÌ fort

The cauÅ¿e that moued me to preÅ¿ent theÅ¿e my firÅ¿t fruits vnto your Honour, was, That partly you had heard them read vnto you, & your Honors accepting of them as fauoring the trueth Å¿hall incourage others to doe the like, and reade them more diligently. I haue not laboured to be curious in this matter, but Å¿o plaine as the weakeÅ¿t of capacitie might eaÅ¿ely vnderÅ¿tande: for whoÅ¿e Å¿ake, and not for the learned I was willing to publiÅ¿h this worke, according to that talent that the Lorde in mercy hath committed vnto me his Å¿eruant, for the building vp of his Å¿pirituall temple. I doubt not, but by the working of Gods holy Å¿pirit in you in reading of theÅ¿e articles nowe and then, your Honour, (being voyde of waightier matters and affayres, when leaÅ¿ure Å¿hall Å¿erue,) you Å¿hall finde Å¿ome comfort and conÅ¿olation in them. Although they be playne, yet are they true, & neede no eloquence to Å¿et them forth: for trueth Å¿eeketh no corners to hide her Å¿elfe in: Onely her feare is leaÅ¿t Å¿he Å¿hould be hid. I graunt, it might Å¿eeme a needleÅ¿Å¿e and fruitleÅ¿Å¿e thing to write bookes and publiÅ¿he them in theÅ¿e dayes, wherein are Å¿uch Å¿tore that nowe bookes lacke readers, rather then readers want bookes: but if a man conÅ¿ider well with him Å¿elfe, he Å¿hall finde that a great many of them tende not Å¿o much to Å¿et forth godlines, as wantonnes: neither do they profit the Church and common wealth, but rather hurt and hinder it as much as in them lyeth, Å¿o that it had bene better

Å¿o then although the Å¿tore of bookes in our dayes is great, yet the number of them that encreaÅ¿e true godlineÅ¿Å¿e, is not Å¿o great, but that it may be augmeÌted. div.head: The firÅ¿t Sermon vpon the firÅ¿t article, I beleue in God the father almightie, maker of heauen and earth.
div.p:
BEfore we come to Å¿peake of the meaning of theÅ¿e wordes, it Å¿hall not be amiÅ¿Å¿e to coÌÅ¿ider in a word or two, who made this ChriÅ¿tian order and forme of our beliefe. The generall and common opinion receaued with the whole conÅ¿ent of the Church, is, that the xii. ApoÅ¿tles of our Å¿auiour IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, made this Creede, euery one an article, as a godly writer of our time, one Aretius in his booke of queÅ¿tions doeth Å¿hew. Therefore it is called the ApoÅ¿tles Creede. But whether it were they or no that made it, or any other, it is no great matter, Å¿eeing it is all the vndoubted trueth of Gods worde, & euery poynt of it agreeth with the reÅ¿t of the holy Å¿criptures written with the Spirit of ChriÅ¿t. We haue many bookes in the olde & new TeÅ¿tament, which are written for our conÅ¿olation & comfort, and that by the finger of God, but yet we knowe not the names of thoÅ¿e men that
wrote them, as the booke of the Iudges, the booke of Kinges, and the Chronicles, and Å¿uch like: and in the newe TeÅ¿tament the EpiÅ¿tle to the Ebrewes. TheÅ¿e all are the holy worde of God, but yet we knowe not the authors of them. And it Å¿eemeth that the holy GhoÅ¿t woulde haue their names Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed and vnknowen, becauÅ¿e we Å¿houlde receiue all Scripture alike, and with the Å¿ame authoritie which proceedeth from the mouth of God, making no differeÌce of perÅ¿ons, or choyÅ¿e of men, when all is trueth that is written, and that we Å¿houlde not conÅ¿ider Å¿o much, who Å¿peaketh or writeth a thing, as what is Å¿poken & written vnto vs. Thus much for the writers of this worke. Nowe let vs conÅ¿ider the thing it Å¿elfe. which are contayned in the laÅ¿t three articles, which are annexed and ioyned vnto the Church, as The remiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿innes, the reÅ¿urrection of the bodie, and the life euerlaÅ¿ting. TheÅ¿e are the benefites which followe the Church. This is the diuiÅ¿ion of the Creede. Out of the firÅ¿t article we haue to note theÅ¿e two things: firÅ¿t that we muÅ¿t beleeue in God: Å¿econdly, what maner of God it is, in whome we doe beleeue. The meaning of theÅ¿e wordes is this, I the Å¿eruant and childe of God, I, I Å¿ay, & not another for me, doe beleeue, hope and truÅ¿t in one almightie, eternall & euerliuing God, which is not only a God of might vnto me, to be able to do all thinges, but a moÅ¿t mercifull father in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, moÅ¿t willing and ready to helpe me in al troubles and aduerÅ¿ities of this life, when I Å¿hall cry & call vnto him. FirÅ¿t therefore we learne here to beleeue & truÅ¿t in God only, and not in any creature whatÅ¿oeuer, for they cannot helpe vs, as Dauid Å¿ayeth in his PÅ¿almes, Vaine is the helpe of man. It is thou that Å¿aueÅ¿t me from mine aduerÅ¿aries. And here note, that there is a great differeÌce betwene theÅ¿e three, to beleeue God, & to beleeue there is a God, & to beleeue in God, the deuils beleue
the firÅ¿t & the Å¿econd, that God is true of his word and promiÅ¿e, which is, to beleeue God, & they alÅ¿o beleeue there is one God and no moe, and tremble, as S. Iames the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayth, Chap. 2. 19. but they beleeue not the third, that is, in God, which is as much as to embrace & acknowledge him for our good God, and to Å¿ticke to him, and to his worde only. This is proper to the Elect & children of God, not to the deuils and reprobates, which doe not truÅ¿t in him. For they lacke a true iuÅ¿tifying faith, which is defined to be a Å¿ure truÅ¿t in the mercies of God & his promiÅ¿es, made vnto vs in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t his Sonne, (by whom he hath adopted vs) that he wil be mercifull vnto vs, & forgiue vs all our Å¿innes. This is faith, & this is it that we muÅ¿t haue, when we Å¿ay, I beleeue in God. For faith muÅ¿t looke vnto God, & not to any man or angel, or Å¿aint in heauen. Therefore Paul Å¿aid to the iayler, aÅ¿king howe he might be Å¿aued, when he had abuÅ¿ed & cruelly handled the ApoÅ¿tles,Actes 16. So that this doctrine to beleeue in God & in no other, is a doctrine of comfort to al the godly, and to Å¿ettle their hearts that they be not troubled or caried away with vaine perÅ¿uaÅ¿ions of men and of Angels, which Paul forbiddeth, ColoÅ¿. 2. But here may a queÅ¿tion be made, why we Å¿ay not, as in the Lordes prayer in the plurall number, Our Father, and forgiue vs our treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es: Å¿o here alÅ¿o in like Å¿ort, why Å¿ay we not, We beleeue in God? FirÅ¿t I anÅ¿were, that is a prayer to God, & this is a confeÅ¿Å¿ion of our faith. Then I Å¿ay the caÅ¿e is not all one or alike. For I may pray for another man,1. And this doth teach vs to apply the mercies of God vnto our Å¿elues, Å¿aying, I beleeue as well as other men, yt God wil help me, & be my father. This is a great coÌfort which the godly only haue, and not ye wicked, as Dauid Å¿aith, The Lorde is his Lorde as wel as he is a lord to other. Thus much on whoÌ we muÅ¿t beleeue, yt is, in God only. Now Å¿ecoÌdly conÅ¿ider wt your Å¿elues in what maner of god you doe beleeue and truÅ¿t: not in Å¿uch a one as the Paynims did, that could not help them, as Iupiter, Apollo,

div.head: The Å¿econde Lecture vpon the creede, which is vpon the Å¿econde article: And in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t his onely Å¿onne our Lorde, which was conceiued by the holy GhoÅ¿t.
div.p:
WE haue Å¿eene in the firÅ¿t article going before, the thinges, which we haue to beleeue as concerning God the father in his creation: now followeth conÅ¿equently what we haue to beleeue of God the Å¿onne, IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, as concerning his incarnation and all the benefites of his death and paÅ¿Å¿ion, which is the Å¿econd part of the creede, as we deuided it. And here in this article you muÅ¿t vnderÅ¿tande and repeate, as in the former, Å¿o in this alÅ¿o: I beleeue in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t: that is, I truÅ¿t in him, and put my whole confidence in him, that hee is my onely Å¿auiour, and that God will for his Å¿ake forgiue me all my Å¿innes. For it is not Å¿ufficient to beleeue in God the father, & to know him, vnleÅ¿Å¿e we alÅ¿o beleeue in his only begotten Å¿onne IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿te our Lorde, and knowe him alÅ¿o. As Iohn repeating the wordes of
our Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t, Å¿aith, This is life eternal that they know thee to be the onely very God, & whom thou haÅ¿t Å¿ent, IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. Ioh. 17. So that our Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t ioyneth and matcheth in one, the knowledge of him Å¿elfe with the knowledge of the father, as he Å¿ayeth alÅ¿o in another place, Except ye beleeue that I am he, ye Å¿hal die in your Å¿ins. We Å¿ee then yt if we muÅ¿t beleeue in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, he is one God with the father, and a creator, other wiÅ¿e it were idolatry to beleue in any that is not God. And yt we may beleue in him, this is warraÌted vnto vs by his owne commandement, Å¿aying in the 19. of Iohns goÅ¿pel to his diÅ¿ciples, Let not your heart be troubled, beleeue ye in God, beleeue alÅ¿o in me. A notable place to prooue this matter. Where we may alÅ¿o learne, yt if we beleeue in God, our hearts Å¿hal not be troubled, nor wauer hither & thither, not hauing any place to reÅ¿t in. For therfore in our miÅ¿eries & daÌgers are we vexed & troubled out of meaÅ¿ure, becauÅ¿e we put not our full truÅ¿t in the father & the Å¿onne. Nowe let vs Å¿ee with what titles our ChriÅ¿t is beautified & adorned with, for our coÌfort & conÅ¿olation: firÅ¿t of all, he is here called IeÅ¿us, which is an Ebrew word, & Å¿ouÌdeth in EngliÅ¿h as
much as Sauiour, which name the Angell gaue vnto him (by Gods appoyntment) before he was conceaued in the wombe of the virgin Mary his mother. As we reade notably Å¿et forth vnto vs in the firÅ¿t of Matth: Shee Å¿hal bring foorth a Å¿onne, and cal his name IeÅ¿us, or Å¿auiour: for he Å¿hall Å¿aue his people from their Å¿innes and offences. And for this cauÅ¿e he came into the worlde, as he teÅ¿tifieth of him Å¿elf: The Å¿onne of maÌ came to Å¿aue that which is loÅ¿t, not to deÅ¿troy Å¿oules, but to Å¿aue, and to giue his life a redemption for many, Luk. 19. By this we learne, that there is no other Sauiour appoynted for maÌ, either in heaueÌ, or earth, but only IeÅ¿us: and they that wil haue Å¿aluation of God the father, muÅ¿t haue it onely at his handes. Therefore doeth the Å¿cripture pronounce of him, that there is no other name giuen vnder heauen vnto men, wherein they muÅ¿t be Å¿aued, but only in the name of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. For this is the Å¿tone which is become the head Å¿tone, and the chiefe in the corner, neither is there any Å¿aluation in any other, Act. 4. We haue then to Å¿eek our Å¿aluation not in Angels, not in Å¿aints, not in men or in our Å¿elues: but in him onely that hath the key of Dauid, that Å¿hutteth heauen, and
no man openeth it, and openeth it, & no man Å¿hutteth. This is the firÅ¿t title of dignitie and honour, that is giuen vnto him of his father: the next is, that hee is called ChriÅ¿t, which is a Greeke word, and Å¿ignifieth in EngliÅ¿h, Anoynted, which doth more plainly & effectually declare his office & function giuen him of the father for vs. For he was anoynted for three eÅ¿peciall purpoÅ¿es: firÅ¿t to bee our Prophet to teach vs, Å¿econdly, our prieÅ¿t to offer him Å¿elfe a Å¿acrifice for vs, and thirdly, our king to rule & to defeÌd vs from our enemies. TheÅ¿e things are al giueÌ vnto vs to vnderÅ¿tande in this name ChriÅ¿t. For as al the Prophets, and prieÅ¿tes and kinges in the time of the olde law, before the comming of ChriÅ¿t, were anoynted with oyle by the commandement of God, as God coÌmanded Elias to anoynt EliÅ¿eus Prophet in his Å¿tead, & MoÅ¿es was coÌmaunded to anoynt Aaron hye prieÅ¿t, and Samuel to anoynt Saul & Dauid to be kinges: Å¿o was ChriÅ¿t alÅ¿o anoynted, not with oyle materiall as they, but with Å¿piritual oyle of gladneÅ¿Å¿e, as Dauid Å¿aieth,PÅ¿al. 45. 7. aboue his fellowes, yt is, with ye holy ghoÅ¿t, aboue al meÌ, for he had it without meaÅ¿ure, Ioh. 3. 34. So then, as ye Prophets & prieÅ¿ts, & kings were all figures, &
Å¿hadowes of ChriÅ¿t anoynted with oyle, to Å¿ignifie yt they muÅ¿t be gentle, meeke, & Å¿oft to al their brethren: Å¿o it was alÅ¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary, yt ChriÅ¿t Å¿hould performe al this yt was prefigured by him. And firÅ¿t we Å¿ee, yt ChriÅ¿t toke vpon him the office of a Prophet, to teach ye people his fathers wil, not thruÅ¿ting in him Å¿elfe as the falÅ¿e prophetes did, whom the Lord Å¿ent not at al, but being thereto lawefully called & authoriÅ¿ed by his father from heauen,Luk 9. 35. Å¿aying, Heare him, that is, to be our doctour and teacher, our Prophete and ScholemaÅ¿ter. Being thus ordayned a Prophet to teach vs, he executed his office and calling moÅ¿t diligently, moÅ¿t paynfully and faithfully: for he taught them in Å¿eaÅ¿on and out of Å¿eaÅ¿on, earely and late, at home & abroad, by Å¿ea and by land, as ye EuangeliÅ¿ts doe Å¿ufficiently all of them record in their goÅ¿pels, neither did he teach theÌ ye wil of his father publikely in ye Å¿ynagogues only, but priuately alÅ¿o in families & houÅ¿es: as when he was receiued into Marthas houÅ¿e, he Å¿ate & taught there Mary & others: whereby wee that are the Lordes Prophets & miniÅ¿ters, may learne by this good exaÌple, howe carefully & readyly with al payne and diligence to behaue our Å¿elues in the preaching of the

We learne againe, that no man beÅ¿ide ChriÅ¿te, was able to inÅ¿truct vs in the will of his father, but hee alone, as Iohn Å¿ayth, Chap. 1. No man hath Å¿eene God at any time: the only begotten Å¿on of God, which is in the boÅ¿ome of his father, he hath reuealed him vnto vs. Againe, we vnderÅ¿tand that al men by nature are ignorant of the will of God, & their dutie, becauÅ¿e we haue neede of ChriÅ¿t to informe vs in the right way, to leade vs in the trueth, leaÅ¿t we be deceued with lyes. For of his fulneÅ¿Å¿e haue wee all receiued, Ioh. 1. Therefore is he called of EÅ¿ay, The angel of great CounÅ¿ell, and that the Å¿pirit of the Lord Å¿hould reÅ¿t vpon him, the Å¿pirit of wiÅ¿edome & vnderÅ¿tanding, the Å¿pirit of CounÅ¿el and Å¿trength, the Å¿pirit of knowledge and of the feare of the Lord, IÅ¿a. 11.
This is a great comfort to vs, to haue Å¿uch a teacher and Prophet giuen to vs, as is made to vs of God, wiÅ¿edome. 1. Corin. 1. But the wicked can haue here no part at all with him, for they do not heare his word and voyce, neither wil they receiue his doctrine & inÅ¿truction. Nowe we Å¿ee how faithfully ChriÅ¿t hath fulfilled this office of preaching, as Marke Å¿ayth of him, 1. Chap. Let vs goe into the next Townes, that I may preache there alÅ¿o, for I came out for that purpoÅ¿e. The Å¿econd office that is in ChriÅ¿t for his Church, is his prieÅ¿thode: for after hee had taught the people, (which thing he firÅ¿t tooke in hand) hee Å¿ealed his doctrine with his owne blood, and offered vp him Å¿elfe a Å¿acrifice moÅ¿t perfect, Å¿weete and acceptable to God his father, for vs al, to purge vs from our Å¿innes, to Å¿erue the liuing God. father Å¿aith of him,PÅ¿al. 110. 5. Thou art a PrieÅ¿t for euer, after the order of MelchieÅ¿edech. Of this Å¿acrifice Å¿peaketh abundantly the EpiÅ¿tle to the Hebremes, but eÅ¿pecially in the 9. And againe, that the blood of ChriÅ¿t, which through ye eternal Å¿pirit offered himÅ¿elfe without fault to God, Å¿hall purge our conÅ¿ciences from dead workes to Å¿erue the liuing God, Å¿o that nowe he is become our mediatour betweene God & vs, & doeth appeare in the Å¿ight of God for vs. This is a great comfort for vs. But we Å¿ee in this Å¿acrifice the vileneÅ¿Å¿e & greatneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿inne, & how lothÅ¿ome & deteÅ¿table it was in Gods Å¿ight, that nothing in heauen or earth could put it away or purge it, but the onely body & blood of ChriÅ¿t, this hie prieÅ¿t, moÅ¿t pure and immaculate. And this driueth vs to coÌÅ¿ider how we are indebted to our good Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t, for dying Å¿o mercifully for vs: Å¿o that wee are worÅ¿e then beaÅ¿ts, vnleÅ¿Å¿e we giue him continuall thanks for it. So that nowe wee which were Å¿ometime farre off & Å¿trangers from the coÌmon wealth of IÅ¿rael, are made neere by ye blod of ChriÅ¿t, to offer our Å¿elues to him & al ours, our prayers, our thanks, & yt with boldneÅ¿Å¿e, without feare, as Zachary Å¿ayth, Luk. 1. The third office yt we conÅ¿ider in him, is his Å¿pirituall & euerlaÅ¿ting kingdom, for Å¿piritual it is, & not carnal & earthly, as he himÅ¿elf Å¿aid to Pilate, My kingdoÌ is not of this world. Reue. 3. SecoÌdly, this kingdom of ChriÅ¿t doth beat downe al force rayÅ¿ed vp againÅ¿t his kingdome: as the deuil, the Turke, the Pope, the wicked ones of this world. When we Å¿ay that ChriÅ¿t was conceiued in the wombe of the virgin Marie his mother, by the operation and worke of ye holy ghoÅ¿t, we meane that to bee Å¿poken according to his humanitie only, and not according to his diuinitie: for Å¿o hee is likened to MelchiÅ¿edech, without father as touching his fleÅ¿h, & without

Therfore we muÅ¿t wiÅ¿ely diÅ¿tinguÅ¿h & make a differeÌce betweene yâ¢ two natures & properties of ChriÅ¿t, his maÌhod & Godhead. WheÌ ChriÅ¿t Å¿aith, he can of him Å¿elf do nothing, he iudgeth no maÌ, he knoweth not the day of iudgemeÌt, & that ye father is greater theÌ hee, with Å¿uch like Å¿enteÌ ces in yt GoÅ¿pel, you muÅ¿t vnderÅ¿tand theÅ¿e things to be Å¿pokeÌ as he was only man. IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. FirÅ¿t, that he was conceiued, as the word doth teÅ¿tifie. Nowe let vs giue moÅ¿t huÌ ble and heartie thankes as we are bound, to this IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, yâ¢ being Å¿o hie, he woulde vouchÅ¿afe to deÅ¿cende Å¿o lowe for vs poore wretches, as to be conceiued in the wombe of a maide to make vs pure: and let vs alÅ¿o pray vnto his MaieÅ¿tie, yt Å¿eeing his conceptioÌ is pure & vnÅ¿potted, he would alÅ¿o make ours Å¿o to be, with the free imputatioÌ of his conception & all other benefites of his death and paÅ¿Å¿ion, & that he would kill Å¿inne in vs more and more daily, by his Å¿pirit of Å¿anctification, that we may liue here in righteouÅ¿nes and holines before him without feare, al the daies of our life, & wheÌ the Å¿infull courÅ¿e of this traÌÅ¿itorie life is ended, we may haue that life which neuer Å¿hall haue ende, whoÅ¿e ioyes neither eye hath Å¿eene, nor eare hath heard, nor heart of maÌ can poÅ¿Å¿ibly conceiue or thinke: which God grant vnto vs for his Sonne ChriÅ¿ts Å¿ake: to whom wt the holie ghoÅ¿t, be rendred al power, dominioÌ, praiÅ¿e and thankeÅ¿giuing, both now and for euer. div.p: IN this article is mentioned and Å¿et downe vnto vs the natiuitie and birth of our Sauiour IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, how that he was borne, not after the coÌ mon Å¿ort of men, but of a maide or virgin, not a married woman which knewe any man: Å¿o that the meaning of this article in moe wordes is this, I that am a ChriÅ¿tian man or woman, doe beleeue alÅ¿o, that as IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t was conceyued by the holy GhoÅ¿t, Å¿o was he borne likewiÅ¿e for mee of his mother Marie, Å¿he notwithÅ¿tanding remayning Å¿till a virgin. God then, as in this, Å¿o in all other things, is true and iuÅ¿t of his promiÅ¿e and couenant, that he maketh to a thouÅ¿and generatioÌs, as Å¿aith the Prophet. And although it be Å¿aid that Marie was maried to IoÅ¿eph, & IoÅ¿eph tooke her home to him to be his wife, yet Å¿he was a virgin, for IoÅ¿eph knewe her not: Å¿o yt ChriÅ¿t was borne of her being a virgin, & IoÅ¿eph was Å¿pouÅ¿ed to her in this reÅ¿pect, that he Å¿hould be an aide and comfort for her in her trouble and paine, in her flight into Egypt, & in her great pouertie: for Å¿he was Å¿o poore, that Å¿he had no chamber to be deliuered in, but laid our Sauiour ChriÅ¿t in a manger. 2 Secondly, for our inÅ¿truction let vs

Luke doth declare ye order of it very liuely, & Å¿aith, yt wheÌ IoÅ¿eph & Mary were at Bethlehem, the dayes were accompliÅ¿hed that Å¿hee Å¿houlde be deliuered, & Å¿he brought forth her firÅ¿t begotten Å¿onne, and wrapped him in Å¿wadling clothes, and layde him in a cratch or manger, becauÅ¿e there was no roume for theÌ in the Inne. This doth paÅ¿Å¿e the reach and capacitie of mans witte, and doth expreÅ¿Å¿e vnto vs, how that the Lords waies are not our wayes, nor his doinges as ours are: For then Å¿urely woulde hee not haue had ChriÅ¿t his Sonne to bee borne Å¿o poorely, and without al honour and eÅ¿timation here in the earth. Å¿o yt he himÅ¿elfe doth pronounce to one that would folow him for gaine & eÅ¿timatioÌ in this life, yt the Å¿onne of maÌ, meaning him Å¿elf, hath not where to lay or hide his hed, but is in worÅ¿e caÅ¿e theÌ ye foxes which haue holes, or ye birds of ye aire which haue their neÅ¿ts, Mat. 8. The circumÅ¿tances of his birth, are the place of it, and the tyme. As concerning the place, Matthewe and Luke both agree in one, that it was Bethlehem, for Å¿o was it long before prophecyed of by the Prophet Micheas. Chap. 5. Å¿aying, And thou Bethlehem Ephrathah, art little to be among the thouÅ¿ands

Where hee Å¿etteth foorth vnto vs plainely, both the humanitie of ChriÅ¿t, and alÅ¿o his diuinitie: his humanitie, in that hee Å¿ayth, hee came out of Bethlehem: and his diuinitie, in that his going foorth was from euerlaÅ¿ting. The place then was Bethlehem: no great and famous citie as IeruÅ¿alem was, but a poore and obÅ¿cure towne, nothing Å¿poken of among men. Howe hath ChriÅ¿t viÅ¿ited vs in mercy, in giuing vs his holy GoÅ¿pel the foode of our Å¿oules, as much as euer hee did to the Iewes? and yet I Å¿ay wee are troubled Å¿till in our mindes and Å¿oules, with ye cares of this world, which do choke the Å¿eede of his holy word. Wel (dearly beloued) let vs learne to be wiÅ¿e, and to conÅ¿ider thankfully of Gods benefites in time, leÅ¿t they be takeÌ from vs, as they were from the Iewes, and giuen to a nation that Å¿hal better receiue them, and make greater account of them. The third thing yt I Å¿aide was to be conÅ¿idered in the birth of our Å¿auiour IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, is the profite and comfort yt we may take & apply to our Å¿elues, our Å¿oules and bodyes by it, and what duetie is required of vs in this behalfe. The commoditie that ariÅ¿eth to vs and al ChriÅ¿tians by his birth, is, that ChriÅ¿t came to Å¿aue that which was loÅ¿t, as Paul doth notably expreÅ¿Å¿e the ende of his comming in the fleÅ¿he, Å¿aying, This is a true Å¿aying, and by all meanes woorthy to bee receyued, that IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t came into this worlde to Å¿aue Å¿inners, 1. We may Å¿aye therefore, that a man is borne of the virgin Marie, the true and naturall Å¿onne of Adam, of Abraham, of Dauid, which was promiÅ¿ed in the lawe and Prophets, Å¿uch a man I Å¿ay, that hath conquered hell and death, and damnation, & deÅ¿iuered vs from the wrath of his father to come. for vs in heauen already: the other, yt by the participation & vnitie of his nature wt ours, he receiueth & admitteth vs into the Å¿ocietie of him Å¿elfe, and all his riches and treaÅ¿ures are made ours, euen as the wife may Å¿ay of her huÅ¿band, that al her huÅ¿baÌds goods & lands are hers, becauÅ¿e Å¿he is one with him: Å¿o may we Å¿ay of our moÅ¿t gratious huÅ¿band & bridegrome IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, that all his Å¿tore is now become ours: For we are bones of his bones, and fleÅ¿h of his fleÅ¿h, as Paul telleth vs plainly, EpheÅ¿. 5. If this be Å¿o, then wee ought to reioyce and be glad in our heartes, as Paul Å¿ayth, which is, in the Lorde, becauÅ¿e that ChriÅ¿t the great iewell of God is Å¿ent into the worlde. If we greatly reioyce & triumphe, when wee haue a mortall Å¿onne an heyre here borne in earth vnto vs, whoÌ we knowe not whether he Å¿hall be good or ill, a coÌfort or paine vnto vs: If (I Å¿ay) we do reioyce at this vanity, what ought we to do (think ye) dearly beloued brethreÌ, wheÌ we heare yt Å¿oÌne of God to be borne for vs, & the heire of all things, a Å¿onne that pacifieth his fathers wrath iuÅ¿tly conceiued againÅ¿t Å¿inne, Å¿uch a childe as maketh vs children, & bringeth vs into his heauenly poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion & inheritance?
Ought we not (trow you) vnÅ¿peakeably to reioyce, & thanke God and his Å¿onne ChriÅ¿t continually? It is good reaÅ¿on Å¿o to do, Å¿eeing it is our onely benefit, and not his: for he came and was borne for vs, and not for him Å¿elfe. The angels of God herein may teach vs our duety, howe thankfull we ought to be, and to reioyce for it, not with a worldly and carnal ioy, as many do, but with a Å¿pirituall and heauenly ioy of minde and conÅ¿cience, as few doe. At the birth of our Å¿auiour, there was a company and multitude of heauenly Å¿ouldiers prayÅ¿ing God, and Å¿aying, Glory be to God in the high heauens, and peace in the earth, and towards men good will, Luke 2. They reioyced in the Lord, & were thankful for it, & yet are: much more ought we to do the like, that his wil may be done in earth of vs, as it is in heauen amongÅ¿t them, euen as we dayly pray. Thy wil be done in earth, as it is in heauen. We haue in deede a celebration of this natiuitie of ChriÅ¿t, which is miÅ¿called of vs ChriÅ¿tmas. As ye name is euil, called ChriÅ¿tmas of the PapiÅ¿ts, as if ChriÅ¿t Å¿hould Å¿ay MaÅ¿Å¿e: Å¿o is the time in it Å¿pent as lewdly of vs for the moÅ¿t part, if not in maÅ¿Å¿ing, yet in maÅ¿king, in carding and dicing, in dauncing, in bellie
cheere, in exceÅ¿Å¿e of apparrell, and in fond and fooliÅ¿he playes & Å¿portes, to paÅ¿Å¿e the time away. In theÅ¿e Å¿innes and vanities, is the tyme of ChriÅ¿tes natiuitie Å¿pent and conÅ¿umed of vs. It were better to haue no day of it, then Å¿o to keepe it: and it is a great griefe to a godly mynde, to Å¿ee that tyme which Å¿houlde be imployed to the Å¿eruice of God, as it was in the primitiue Church, altogether waÅ¿ted and dedicated to offer Å¿acrifices vnto the deuill: for it is in it, as it is vpon the Sundayes or Lordes day thoroughout the yeere. The Sabbath which is appoynted for to heare Gods woorde, and to pray in, is turned altogether to play in, and made a day of all wicked Å¿port and paÅ¿time, which is far from the ryght vÅ¿e of it, & yet no MagiÅ¿trate doeth correct it. God giue an amendement one day of it, to his honour and glory. Amen. Well, Å¿o it is with this time of our Sauiours birth: we Å¿houlde giue thankes in it, and wee neuer thinke of our duetie in it the moÅ¿t part of vs. If Emperours and Kinges haue celebrated the memoriall of their birth dayes, then there is greater reaÅ¿on, why we Å¿hould remember the ioyfulleÅ¿t birth day that euer was, or Å¿halbe, I meane, of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t
our Å¿auiour, borne Å¿o poorely and Å¿imply for vs. Not that we Å¿hould Å¿o celebrate and keepe ChriÅ¿ts birth day, as wicked Herode did celebrate his natiuitie, in feaÅ¿ting, in daunÅ¿ing, in raÅ¿h Å¿wearing, and laÅ¿t of all, in murdering the good Å¿aint of God, Iohn BaptiÅ¿t, Matth. 14. Mark. 6. I Å¿ay, we muÅ¿t not Å¿o celebrate this birth day of ChriÅ¿t with him, leaÅ¿t wee be partakers of his puniÅ¿hment and payne. But yet I feare a great many doe keepe this time no better. Neither muÅ¿t we keepe this day of our brother ChriÅ¿tes birth, as Titus kept the birth day of his brother Domitian, in killing the Iewes for his pleaÅ¿ure, to triumphe, and Å¿o defiled his handes with innocent blood, Å¿urely we do not much better: for although we kill not with the Å¿worde, yet we wound and kill our brethren with our tongues, we quarrel, we fight, and are contentious, wee Å¿weare and blaÅ¿pheme, and Å¿o reuile the liuing Lorde, and this is done moÅ¿t of all at the birth day of our Sauiour, as alÅ¿o vpon this day of reÅ¿t, the Sunday, with cardes and dice & bloody othes. Wel, the Lord one day will take an account of theÅ¿e things of vs, vnleÅ¿Å¿e we Å¿peedily repent and amende. Thus we haue heard the thinges that may
be noted vpon ChriÅ¿tes birth, the circumÅ¿tances of it, with the fruite that commeth vnto vs by it, and howe wee Å¿houlde vÅ¿e this day, and what is our duetie in it. Let vs thanke our Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t, that he woulde be thus borne for vs, and pray vnto him that we may remember it, and haue the ende of this his coÌming in ye fleÅ¿h, the Å¿aluatioÌ of our foules, which he grauÌt vnto vs: to whom wt his father, and the holy ghoÅ¿t, be giuen all prayÅ¿e and glory, for euer and euer: Amen.

div.head: The fourth Lecture vpoÌ the 4. article of our ChriÅ¿tian faith:
Suffered vnder Pontius Pilate, was crucified, dead, and buried, deÅ¿cended into hell.
div.p:
WE haue Å¿eene in the other two articles going before, the coÌception of ChriÅ¿t and his birth, and what things were in them to be conÅ¿idered of: now coÌÅ¿equeÌtly foloweth his death with certayne circumÅ¿tances of it, as what foloweth after it. But here may a queÅ¿tion be aÅ¿ked, why there is no mention made of his life, which went betweene his birth and death. To this it may be anÅ¿wered, that Å¿eeing
the benefites of his life be coÌprehended in his death (for whatÅ¿oeuer he did in al his whole life, we inioy it in his paÅ¿Å¿ion) therefore his life is not here Å¿et down, becauÅ¿e we do beleeue it in his death. This article of ChriÅ¿ts death is very neceÅ¿Å¿ary; for nothing had bene brought to paÅ¿Å¿e for our Å¿aluation, neither Å¿hould we haue had any profite at al by ChriÅ¿t, vnleÅ¿Å¿e he had bin crucified for vs. Therefore it is not Å¿ufficient to beleeue his conception & natiuitie, except we alÅ¿o confeÅ¿Å¿e with our mouthes, and beleeue in our hearts Å¿tedfaÅ¿tly his death and bitter paÅ¿Å¿ion for vs. Therfore ChriÅ¿t is alwayes to be coÌ Å¿idered of a ChriÅ¿tian man, as he was crucified for his Å¿innes. The meaning of this article is this in other words: I yt am a chriÅ¿tian man or woman, do beleeue & confeÅ¿Å¿e, yt ChriÅ¿t my Å¿auiour Å¿uffered, wheÌ Pilate was deputy in Iurie, & was condemned by him moÅ¿t vniuÅ¿tly, and that he was crucified vpoÌ the croÅ¿Å¿e or tree for my Å¿innes, to redeeme me, & that he died for me, to bring me to life, & that he was buried and laide in the graue as other men, & Å¿uffered ye tormeÌts of hell in body & Å¿oule, to acquit me before ye iudgement Å¿eat of God his father. In this article are fiue things noted vnto vs. FirÅ¿t, vnder
whom he Å¿uffered, & what iudge condemned him: Å¿econdly, what maner of death he died, he was crucified: thirdly, his death it Å¿elfe: fourthly, what was done after, he was buried: & laÅ¿tly, what paines he Å¿uffered, he deÅ¿cended into hel. Al theÅ¿e things are expreÅ¿Å¿ed vnto vs in this one article: firÅ¿t is declared vnto vs the name of him that condemned ChriÅ¿t, which is Pilate a Romane, as Iohn 19. And this his name is Å¿et downe, not only for the credit of the hiÅ¿torie to beleeue it the better, but alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e this appertained to the miÅ¿terie of our redemptioÌ, that we might knowe his death to bee ioyned with the condemnation of an earthly iudge. For Å¿eeing that by ye death of ChriÅ¿t not onely our Å¿innes muÅ¿t bee purged, but alÅ¿o the condemnation for them to be taken away: it was neceÅ¿Å¿ary that hee Å¿hould die by the Å¿entence of a iudge, and no otherwiÅ¿e, that we might be abÅ¿olued before the great iudge of all the worlde. If ChriÅ¿t had been killed by theefes, or murdered in a tumult or Å¿edition by priuate men, there had bene no redemption for vs in Å¿uch a death, no kinde of Å¿atiÅ¿faction. But when we reade in the EuangeliÅ¿tes in their GoÅ¿pell, that he was arraigned at the barre, accuÅ¿ed
by witneÅ¿Å¿es, and condemned by the Å¿entence of Pilate, (although iniuriouÅ¿lye, hee pronouncing him iuÅ¿t, once or twiÅ¿e, & confeÅ¿Å¿ing that he found no fault in him) we vnderÅ¿tand by thoÅ¿e thinges, that hee Å¿uÅ¿tayned not the perÅ¿on of him Å¿elfe, but of al vs moÅ¿t miÅ¿erable Å¿inners, that Å¿hould haue bene Å¿o condemned before his father, if he had not Å¿uffered this vnder Pontius Pilate for vs. And here are two things to be noted of vs, which are both confirmed by the teÅ¿timonies of the Prophets, and do alÅ¿o giue a notable conÅ¿olation and confirmation to our fayth: for when wee heare that ChriÅ¿te was Å¿ent to death, from the iudgement Å¿eate, and was hanged betwene the theeues, wee haue a full accompliÅ¿hment of that propheÅ¿ie, which is cited of the EuaÌgeliÅ¿t, He was reckoned or counted among the wicked, EÅ¿ay. 53. And why was this Å¿o? truely, that he might Å¿uÅ¿taine the condition and eÅ¿tate of a Å¿inner, and not of a iuÅ¿t man, as hee Å¿uffered death, not for righteouÅ¿nes Å¿ake, but for Å¿in and ye tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ions of the wicked. Againe, when we heare that he was pronounced innocent by the Å¿ame man, of whome he was condemned, let vs remember that which another
Prophet Å¿peaketh of him, I reÅ¿tored that which I tooke not, PÅ¿al. 69. yt is, ChriÅ¿t payed for Å¿in, & bought if full dearely, which he neuer had, nor committed: for there was no guile found in his mouth. And why did Pilate then condemne him? BecauÅ¿e he feared man more then God, & CeÅ¿ars diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure more then ye wrath of God: for when ye people cryed, If thou let him goe, thou art not CaeÅ¿ars friend, then he conÅ¿ented vnto them to crucify him againÅ¿t his owne conÅ¿cience, to pleaÅ¿ure the people, & to gratifye ye Emperour Tiberius. So we Å¿ee, that he was a parcial, feareful, & vniuÅ¿t iudge, & had not the properties of a good iudge, as is required, Exod. 18. FirÅ¿t, that they Å¿hould be meÌ of courage, Å¿econdly, fearing God, thirdly, men dealing truely, fourthly, hating couetouÅ¿nes. Let all Iudges take example & warning by Pilate, to execute iuÅ¿tice and iudgement indifferently to all men. For Pilate afterward, as hiÅ¿tories recorde, for anguiÅ¿h and Å¿orowe of minde hanged himÅ¿elfe, as Iudas did before him. And here wee Å¿ee, that as a Romane then condemned ChriÅ¿t, and as alwayes afterwarde hee was perÅ¿ecuted by the Romaine Emperours: Å¿o it is at this day by that great
AntichriÅ¿t of Rome, the Pope and his adherentes: he is Å¿till perÅ¿ecuted in his members. This is the iuÅ¿t iudgement of God vpon them. God giue them grace (if it bee his will) to repent, & to come to the knowledge of the trueth, Amen. Secondly, let vs conÅ¿ider the maner of his death what it was. It was the croÅ¿Å¿e, moÅ¿t Å¿hamefull and accurÅ¿ed, not onely in mans Å¿ight, but alÅ¿o of God him Å¿elfe. Deut. 21. The curÅ¿e of God is on him that is hanged. This Paul repeateth, Gala. 3. and Å¿aith, ChriÅ¿t hath redeemed vs from the curÅ¿e of the lawe, being made a curÅ¿e for vs, for it is written: CurÅ¿ed is euery one that hangeth on tree. Thus we Å¿ee Å¿till in euery article, and in euery point of our Å¿aluation, that exceeding great loue of ChriÅ¿t our maÅ¿ter to vs, that not onely he was contented to Å¿uffer moÅ¿t grieous paine for vs, but alÅ¿o Å¿hame and reproche, ignominie and contempt of the worlde. He was at the firÅ¿t taking, led away to Annas and Caiaphas, and then poÅ¿ted ouer to Pilate. Pilate Å¿ent him to Herode, and Herode Å¿ent him back againe with mockes and tauntes in a purple robe in mockage, & deriÅ¿ion of him. And all this did our Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t for vs. This was
much that I haue rehearÅ¿ed already, but yet nothing to ye death of the croÅ¿Å¿e: for the croÅ¿Å¿e was as odious & Å¿hameful to them, as the gallowes is to vs, & yet ChriÅ¿t was wel contented with it, Å¿o wee might bee redeemed. This is that Paul Å¿peaketh of to the Heb. 12. willing vs to follow the great humilitie of ChriÅ¿t in his Å¿uffering of Å¿hame, Å¿aith, Let vs alÅ¿o, Å¿eeing that we are compaÅ¿Å¿ed with Å¿o great a cloude of witneÅ¿Å¿es, caÅ¿t away euery thing that preÅ¿Å¿eth down, and Å¿inne that hangeth Å¿o faÅ¿t on: let vs runne with patience, the race that is Å¿et before vs, looking vnto IeÅ¿us the author & finiÅ¿her of our faith, who for the ioy that was Å¿et before him, endured the croÅ¿Å¿e, & deÅ¿piÅ¿ed the Å¿hame, and is Å¿et at the right hand of the throne of God. ConÅ¿ider therfore him that endured Å¿uch Å¿peaking agaiÌÅ¿t of Å¿inners, leÅ¿t ye Å¿hould be wearied and faint in your mindes. We Å¿ee many men can abide to Å¿uffer paine and griefe, which yet notwithÅ¿tanding are ouercome with Å¿hame and reproche, and can hardly abide it. One peraduenture could bee contented to Å¿uffer Å¿ome trouble for his deare friende, but who will bee hanged for his friende? Let the Å¿ame minde therefore

You Å¿ee out of this place, howe ChriÅ¿t for our Å¿akes abaÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe to Å¿hame, which conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in foure poyntes. It was much for him being God, to become man, whether it had bene King, or Prince, or Lorde: but it was more to become a miÅ¿erable man, a Å¿eruant vnto men: more then that, it was to die: but moÅ¿t of all was it worthy prayÅ¿e and commendation, that he died the death of the croÅ¿Å¿e, not for his friendes, but for his foes. Many other thinges did our Å¿auiour Å¿uffer of the people, ye Scribes, the PhariÅ¿es, & the Iewes: as reuilings, & blaÅ¿phemies, bitter nippes, and tauntes, but al was nothing to this croÅ¿Å¿e, it Å¿urmounteth all: & yet for all this, we muÅ¿t not be aÅ¿hamed of him, for hee is our glory, Galat. 6. 1. Corinth. 2. they that are aÅ¿hamed of him here in earth before men, he wil be aÅ¿hamed
of theÌ in heaueÌ before his father & his Angels. Let vs therfore confeÅ¿Å¿e and acknowledge ChriÅ¿t crucified for vs, and let vs neuer be aÅ¿hamed of him, when hee commeth with his croÅ¿Å¿e, for he that taketh not vp his croÅ¿Å¿e dayly & followeth him, is not worthy to be his diÅ¿ciple, Luke 9. We Å¿ee then, yt by ChriÅ¿t crucified, the bleÅ¿Å¿ing of Abraham is come vpon vs yt were Gentiles, Galat. 3. and ye the Å¿erpents head is broken, he being yâ¢ true Å¿erpeÌt lifted vp vpon ye croÅ¿Å¿e, to Å¿aue al thoÅ¿e that hope vpon him by fayth, as the other braÅ¿en Å¿erpent lyfted vp by MoÅ¿es in the wildernes, Å¿aued all thoÅ¿e IÅ¿raelites ye were Å¿tong, & looked vp vnto it, Numb. 21. verÅ¿e. 9. Furthermore, by this croÅ¿Å¿e, ye hande writing of ordinances which was againÅ¿t vs, & which was coÌtrary to vs, he, eueÌ he tooke it out of ye way, & faÅ¿tened it vpon the croÅ¿Å¿e, & hath Å¿poyled ye principalities, & powers, & hath made a Å¿hew of theÌ opeÌly, & hath triuÌphed ouer theÌ in ye Å¿ame croÅ¿Å¿e, Col. 2. Of this crucifying, & lifting vp vpoÌ ye croÅ¿Å¿e, was IÅ¿aac a figure, who was bouÌd & laid vpoÌ ye altar,
ready to be offered. And Å¿o were al the Å¿inne offerings layde vpon the altar: for he was made of God his father Å¿inne for vs, that wee might he made the righteouÅ¿nes of God in him, which knewe no Å¿inne, 2. Corinth. 5. But of all other types and Å¿hadowes of the ceremonial lawe, this taking away of Å¿inne by ChriÅ¿t in his croÅ¿Å¿e, was moÅ¿t liuely Å¿et forth and repreÅ¿ented vnto vs, as in a glaÅ¿Å¿e, in the Å¿caps goate. For the Lord commanded Aaron Leuit. 16. that he Å¿hould take a liue hee goate, and preÅ¿ent him quicke before the Lorde, to make reconciliation by him, and that he Å¿hould put his handes vpon the head of the goate, and confeÅ¿Å¿e ouer him all the iniquities of the children of IÅ¿rael, and all their treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es, & all their Å¿innes, putting them vpon the head of the goate, & Å¿hould Å¿end him away, by the hande of a man appointed, into the wildernes: Å¿o the goate Å¿hall beare vpon him all their iniquities into the lande that is not inhabited. Here was our Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t figured, which bare in his body vpoÌ the croÅ¿Å¿e, the iniquities of vs al, EÅ¿ai. 53. 1. Furthermore, this betraying and crucifying of ChriÅ¿t, and Å¿elling of him for thirty pence, was alÅ¿o forefigured in IoÅ¿eph. For as IoÅ¿eph was Å¿olde of his owne brethren into the handes of Å¿trangers: Å¿o was ChriÅ¿t betrayed and Å¿old of his owne diÅ¿ciple, anddeliuered of his owne nation into the handes of Pilate and the Heathen. The third thing that followeth in this article, is his death. He was dead in deede, as the EuangeliÅ¿tes doe report: for Luke Å¿ayth of him, that he cryed with a loude voyce and Å¿ayde, Father, into thy hands I commend my Å¿pirit. So for the certaintie of it, it is not onely Å¿aid that he was crucified, but alÅ¿o that he died: for otherwiÅ¿e nothing had bene wrought for vs. God Å¿ayde to Adam, In what day Å¿oeuer thou Å¿halt eate of the forbidden tree of knowledge of good and euill, thou Å¿halt die the death. Adam offended and brake this commandement: hee was not able to make Å¿atiÅ¿faction for it, to die the death of body and Å¿oule: therfore the Å¿econd Adam IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t died the death of body, & Å¿uffered the death in Å¿oule, to redeeme vs, and to Å¿atiÅ¿fie Gods wrath & diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ure, conceiued

For as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayth, without Å¿hedding of blood was no remiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿innes. This was verified in ChriÅ¿tes blood, Å¿hed for vs in his death. As SamÅ¿on, who died him Å¿elfe to deliuer his people from the PhiliÅ¿tims: Å¿o ChriÅ¿t, to deliuer vs from the deuils, died him Å¿elfe. Dauid alÅ¿o was a figure of him in many thinges. Here we Å¿ee then, what a grieuous thing Å¿inne was in Gods Å¿ight, that he could be pacified by no other meanes, then by the blood & death of his only and welbeloued Sonne IeÅ¿us. Surely our Å¿innes were as hard as the Adamant Å¿tone, which could not be brokeÌ by any other meanes, then by the blood of the true goate IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. ConÅ¿ider here the wonderfull & vnÅ¿peakeable loue of ChriÅ¿t: he would die for vs, yt we might eÅ¿cape: eueÌ as ye Pelicane, which hauing brought forth
her young ones dead, or being Å¿tong & killed by Å¿erpeÌtes, Å¿he pecketh forth her heart blood to reuiue her young ones: Å¿o we, heing conceiued and borne in Å¿inne, and altogether dead in our treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es and offences, EpheÅ¿. 2. Å¿tong of that old and fiery Å¿erpent the diuell, which firÅ¿t beguiled our parents in paradiÅ¿e, and Å¿o hauing the rewarde of Å¿inne which is death: we (I Å¿ay) in this caÅ¿e are reuiued and quickened againe, by the blood of that true Pelicane IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, which hee from his heart hath Å¿head and powred out for vs. Thus we Å¿ee how deeply we are indebted to ChriÅ¿t for his great loue to vs, in dying for our Å¿innes, and yet how fewe remember this death! Many, not once in a day, nay, not once in a weeke, or moneth, I feare, Å¿ome, not once in a whole yeere doe remember it well: they are the more vnthaÌkeful, & vnkind Å¿onnes to God Å¿o good a father, & ChriÅ¿t Å¿o louing a brother. It is ye only thing yt Å¿hould eÅ¿pecially be remeÌbred, although all other things be forgotteÌ. Beleeue me (deare brethreÌ) ChriÅ¿t died not to this ende, yt his death Å¿hould be forgotten, which was Å¿o cruell to him, or yt it Å¿hould be lightly remeÌbred of vs, for yt he might haue vs to remeÌber it ye better, he inÅ¿tituted
his laÅ¿t Å¿upper, in bread & wine: the bread brokeÌ, to put vs in minde of his moÅ¿t pure & pretious body broken & bruiÅ¿ed for our Å¿innes, & that it doeth nouriÅ¿h vs, as the bread doth nouriÅ¿h our bodies: for his fleÅ¿h is meat in deede Iohn 6. The wine ordeined, to put vs in mind of his blood powred out for vs, to waÅ¿h vs from al our Å¿innes, 1. Iohn 1. & that as ye wine doth quench our thirÅ¿t, and refreÅ¿h vs, & comfort our hearts being Å¿oroweful: Å¿o doeth ye blood of ChriÅ¿t al theÅ¿e things vnto vs, in greater meaÅ¿ure and abundance. This doeth alÅ¿o teache vs vnitie & loue together, yt as many grapes make but one wine, and many graynes of corne & wheate make but one lofe of bread: Å¿o Å¿hould we be but one in ChriÅ¿t our head, for we are all members of the Å¿ame body. The other Å¿acrameÌt alÅ¿o of BaptiÅ¿me, doth put vs in minde of ChriÅ¿tes death: for as ye water in baptiÅ¿me doth waÅ¿h the body: Å¿o doeth the blood of ChriÅ¿t waÅ¿h our Å¿oules, and clenÅ¿e them froÌ their filthines. Which thing is repreÅ¿ented vnto vs in our baptiÅ¿me, a Å¿igne of our newe birth and regeneration by the Å¿pirite of ChriÅ¿t. Therefore in our baptiÅ¿me we ought to remember this death, for wee are buried with him

Nowe we Å¿ee, that to the ende we may remember this great benefite of ChriÅ¿tes death, we haue tokens of it, two in number: the Å¿upper of ChriÅ¿t, and baptiÅ¿me: for by theÌ we Å¿hew forth the Lords death, vntil he come againe to iudgemeÌt, 1. Cor. 11. Nowe if any man marueile why we dye, Å¿ince ChriÅ¿t hath died for vs, & taÅ¿ted death once for all men, to make reconciliatioÌ for the Å¿innes of the people, & to Å¿atiÅ¿fie Gods iuÅ¿tice: he may be anÅ¿wered, yt ChriÅ¿t hath taken away the Å¿econd death of the Å¿oule, & not this firÅ¿t & naturall death of the body, which is common to all, for by it we enter into life: and although it be Å¿ometime grieuous to Gods children, yet it is not deadly to them, nay rather, ioyfull, Å¿eeing by it they come to ChriÅ¿t their head, as it was to Paul: I deÅ¿ire, Å¿aith he, to be looÅ¿ed, and to be with ChriÅ¿t, meaning, to die. TheÅ¿. 1. The Lord IeÅ¿us euen in this life, doeth Å¿hewe and Å¿et foorth vnto all the worlde moÅ¿t wonderfull Å¿ignes and tokens, both of his mercy to the elect, and iuÅ¿tice to ye reprobate: but becauÅ¿e his kingdome is not of this worlde, therefore our faith muÅ¿t amount hier to conÅ¿ider of his laÅ¿t comming, wherein hee Å¿hall Å¿hewe as great glorie and maieÅ¿tie, as he did humilitie and meekenes in his firÅ¿t comming in the fleÅ¿h. They doe in deede bende their tongues like bowes, to Å¿hoote out blaÅ¿phemies againÅ¿t the Lord, Å¿aying, Where is the promiÅ¿e of his comming? But let thoÅ¿e men vnderÅ¿tande, that as the Lorde IeÅ¿us was Å¿eene to goe vp into heauen, Å¿o Å¿hall hee come downe agayne from heauen, as the Angels of God reported, Actes 1. 11. It is meete then, and requiÅ¿ite, that he that was (for our Å¿aluation before the iudgement Å¿eat of maÌ) vniuÅ¿tly condemned, Å¿houlde Å¿hewe in the ende howe great his iuriÅ¿dictioÌ and authoritie ouer al fleÅ¿h is, and what his iuÅ¿tice requireth. Seeing then we muÅ¿t all appeare before the iudgement Å¿eate of ChriÅ¿t, to receiue euery man according to his woorkes which he hath done here in his body, whether they be good or bad: for the more orderly proceeding in this matter, let vs coÌ Å¿ider

But before we Å¿peak of theÅ¿e things in order, we muÅ¿t anÅ¿were to an obiection, which is coÌmonly made of the vnÅ¿kilfull and vnlearned againÅ¿t this iudgement: for when they hear of this iudgemeÌt, they aÅ¿ke to what ende it Å¿hall be, Å¿eeing euery man that dieth, is iudged already, either to heauen, or els to hel, as Å¿oone as the breath is out of his body: therefore it may Å¿eeme that this day is Å¿uperfluous & needeles. And to whome God hath giuen this Å¿pirite of adoption, as he doeth to the Elect, he neuer taketh it away: but is Å¿til a teÅ¿timonie vnto their conÅ¿ciences, that they Å¿halbe Å¿aued in the ende, and coÌtinue in the meane Å¿eaÅ¿on in the faith and obedience of ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us their Lorde. Yea Paul is perÅ¿uaded of the Philippians, (and Å¿o muÅ¿t we be of our Å¿elues) that he that hath begunne a good worke in vs, wil
performe it vntill the day of the Lord IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, Philip. 1. And he hath the like to the Corinthians, that God wil confirme them vnto the ende, 1. Cor. 1. And they that are elected, Å¿hal continue: For the giftes and calling of God are without repentance, Rom. 11. S. Iohn a man beloued of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, and to be beleeued before our aduerÅ¿aries, doubted not to Å¿ay and affirme for a trueth, in his Å¿econde EpiÅ¿tle to a vertuous Lady, that the trueth which dwelleth in vs, Å¿halbe with vs for euer. If it Å¿hal remaine with vs for euer, how Å¿hould we doubt, that it can forÅ¿ake vs at any time, either preÅ¿ent or to come? Proue your Å¿elues, Å¿ayth Paul, whether ye are in the faith: examine your Å¿elues: knowe ye not your owne Å¿elues, that IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t is in you, except ye be reprobats? Here he wil haue vs to be throughly perÅ¿waded, that ChriÅ¿t dwelleth in vs, & Å¿o to be Å¿ure of Å¿aluation, vnleÅ¿Å¿e we will be counted reprobates, which God forbid. If ye PapiÅ¿ts wil be counted reprobates, let them then doubt of their Å¿aluation: if not, then let them recant, & be aÅ¿Å¿ured of it with vs, and amend their religion and maners Å¿peedily. Neyther is this doctrine, as Å¿ome ignorant perÅ¿ons terme it, a doctrine of raÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e and
preÅ¿umptuouÅ¿nes, vnles Gods worde teach vs preÅ¿umption. But this is a very comfortable doctrine, as at all times, Å¿o eÅ¿pecially at the houre of death, when our conÅ¿ciences doe accuÅ¿e vs, and Satan aÅ¿Å¿ault vs, and the paynes of death come vpon vs: (I Å¿aye) this doeth comfort weake and feeble conÅ¿ciences not to deÅ¿paire, and the other doctrine of theirs doeth leade men the hye way to deÅ¿peration, to doubt whether they Å¿hall be Å¿aued or no. They Å¿aye, we muÅ¿t feare. It is true: but not feare to bee damned. For there is no damnation to them that are in ChriÅ¿t, which walke not after the fleÅ¿h, but after the Å¿pirit, Rom. 8. Neither muÅ¿t this feare bee without faith and hope: for then it is a Å¿lauiÅ¿h feare of the whippe and Å¿courge, and not a childes feare, to feare to diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e his louing father. Wee muÅ¿t then haue the feare of Å¿onnes, not of hired Å¿eruantes, to feare to offende and diÅ¿pleaÅ¿e Å¿o mercifull and louing a Father, and not to feare and doubt of our Å¿aluation: for it Å¿tandeth not in vs, but in a Å¿urer rocke and grounde, which is IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t: and if we beleeue in him, we Å¿hall haue euerlaÅ¿ting life, Iohn 3. Act. 17.
And yet here we muÅ¿t take heede of another extremitie, which the MeÅ¿Å¿alians certaine heretikes, with the Libertines, AnabaptiÅ¿ts, & that wicked Å¿ect of ye familie of loue, falleth into: for all theÅ¿e preÅ¿ume too much of this Å¿pirit of God, and of their reuelations, becauÅ¿e they ioyne not the Å¿pirite of God with his word, but Å¿eparate it from the word of ChriÅ¿t, and Å¿o it is but a fayned Å¿pirite of their own fantaÅ¿tical braynes, and not from God. Nowe as the PapiÅ¿tes take too litle, Å¿o theÅ¿e men take too much, and whatÅ¿oeuer commeth firÅ¿t into their idle heades, by and by they attribute it to the Å¿pirit of God, be it neuer Å¿o wicked: and Å¿o theÅ¿e commoÌ ly contemne the outwarde worde and preaching of the GoÅ¿pel, with the adminiÅ¿tration of the Sacraments, whereas we knowe that the Å¿pirite goeth, and is giuen by the miniÅ¿terie of the worde, and is ioyned with it, as Acts. 10. we reade, that while Peter Å¿pake the worde, the holy ghoÅ¿t fell on all them that heard the preaching, not before the worde came: for ChriÅ¿t giueth not his Å¿pirit, but by the hearing of his GoÅ¿pell firÅ¿t preached, as Paul Å¿ayde to the EpheÅ¿ians, After ye heard the worde of trueth, the GoÅ¿pel of your Å¿aluation, wherein alÅ¿o
after that ye beleeued, ye were Å¿ealed with the holy Spirite of promiÅ¿e, EpheÅ¿. 1. Here we Å¿ee, if any would pretend the Å¿pirit without the worde, he may bee refuted: for they goe both together, the worde of trueth with the Å¿pirite of promiÅ¿e. For it is not our part to diÅ¿Å¿euer, or diÅ¿ioyne thoÅ¿e two things, which God will haue coupled together in one. And therefore the Prophetes, which myght better haue vÅ¿ed this prerogatiue of the Å¿pirit then they, called alwayes the people to the worde of the Lorde God, Å¿aying, Heare the word of the Lord, Thus Å¿ayeth the Lord: and Å¿till, The mouth of the Lord hath Å¿poken it, EÅ¿ay 1. They pretende not the Å¿pirit without the worde, although they Å¿peake moÅ¿t plentifully by him, 2. EpiÅ¿t. of Peter 1. Chapter. For the prophecie came not in olde time by the will of man: but holy men of God Å¿pake as they were moued by the holy GhoÅ¿t. Furthermore another effecte of this Spirite is to moue the heart of man, when the worde is preached vnto him: for vnleÅ¿Å¿e Gods Spirite perÅ¿wade and worke in our heartes within, when the preacher Å¿oundeth in our eares the outward word, he Å¿hal but Å¿peake as it were in the ayre, & beate the eare of man in vaine.
Paul well conÅ¿idering this, Å¿ayde, that he in deed had planted, and Apollos another preacher had watered the worde, but it is God (Å¿ayeth he) that giueth the increaÅ¿e. And wee knowe that God woorketh all things in the heartes of his children by this Å¿pirite, wherewith hee Å¿ealeth them after they haue heard and beleeued the worde preached, Ephe. 1. and therfore in the place aboue recited, this Å¿pirit is called the Å¿pirit of promiÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e it doeth aÅ¿Å¿ertaine and aÅ¿Å¿ure vs of all the bleÅ¿Å¿inges and promiÅ¿es of God that are made vnto vs. In the Actes it is Å¿ayde, that Lydia a woman being a Å¿eller of purple, came to heare Paul preach the GoÅ¿pel: but marke what Saint Luke Å¿aieth, whoÅ¿e heart (Å¿ayeth he) the Lord opened, that Å¿hee attended to the things which Paul Å¿pake: So that except God open our cloÅ¿ed and hard Å¿hutte hearts, by the Å¿ecret inÅ¿piration of this holy Å¿pirite, in vayne Å¿hall we eyther preach, or the people heare. We haue neede then all of vs (before we come to heare his word) pray to God to giue vs grace to perceyue & vnderÅ¿tand his will and myÅ¿teries, & to Å¿often our Å¿tony hearts, that they may receiue the worde, and to circumciÅ¿e our eares to heare
it. This it that Dauid Å¿ayde, O Lord open thou mine eyes, that I may Å¿ee the wonderfull things of thy Lawe: and againe, O giue me vnderÅ¿tanding, & I wil keepe thy Lawe. Now Dauid knewe very well that all theÅ¿e things were done by the operation of Gods Å¿pirite, as Paul Å¿ayeth, The Å¿pirit hath reuealed theÅ¿e things vnto vs, 1. Cor. 2. for it is hee that helpeth all our infirmities, Rom. 8. This is the marke whereby God doeth Å¿eale and print in the forehead, to be Å¿eene of all men, thoÅ¿e that are his, and without the which no man can truely aÅ¿Å¿ure him Å¿elfe that he belongeth vnto ChriÅ¿t: for as the Å¿ame ApoÅ¿tle witneÅ¿Å¿eth, If any man haue not the Spirite of ChriÅ¿t, the Å¿ame is none of his. Nowe how greatly this holy Å¿pirit is to be deÅ¿ired of all of vs, there is no man that hath read the Scriptures, but well vnderÅ¿tandeth. This made EliÅ¿eus, a notable man, the Å¿choler of Elias, when his maÅ¿ter bad him to aÅ¿ke of him what he would, that he might do it for him before he was taken away from him into heauen, that he aÅ¿ked his Å¿pirite to bee doubled vpon him, whereby he might the better Å¿erue the Lord and his Church in his vocation and calling, 2. King. 2. and Å¿o by this Å¿pirit he wrought
wonderful miracles, and did much good by it to the whole kingdome of IÅ¿rael. Wee Å¿ee by this petition of this notable father & godly man, what we alÅ¿o Å¿houlde eÅ¿pecially deÅ¿ire of God in our prayers: not riches or wealth Å¿o much, which al do periÅ¿h, but this holy Å¿pirite which liueth & remaineth for euer in them that haue him, and can neuer be loÅ¿t or taken away. And this is the Å¿elf Å¿ame thing that our Sauiour ChriÅ¿t would haue vs to aÅ¿ke in our praiers of God his father: for Å¿peaking of praier to his diÅ¿ciples, he Å¿heweth that God his Father is moÅ¿t ready to giue vs our requeÅ¿ts, as Å¿oone as we aÅ¿ke of him: as our earthly father is willing to beÅ¿tow that vpon vs which he is able to giue. And of all other things that God giueth, he maketh mention of this Å¿pirit, Å¿aying, If ye which are euill, can giue good giftes vnto your children, how much more Å¿hall your heauenly Father giue ye holy GhoÅ¿t to theÌ that deÅ¿ire him? Luk. 11. Signifying this Spirite to be the excellenteÅ¿t gift that God coulde giue, or we deÅ¿ire of him. We haue nowe heard the meaning of this article, of the holy GhoÅ¿t, what it is, and what are the wonderfull and comfortable effectes of it in the Church, and howe the Lorde hath
promiÅ¿ed neuer to leaue his deÅ¿titute of it vnto the worlds ende: We haue Å¿eene alÅ¿o howe we muÅ¿t beleeue in him, as the true and euerlaÅ¿ting God, equally proceeding from the Father and the Sonne, becauÅ¿e he is the power and vertue, whereby they doe worke and create all things. Seeing therefore this heauenly Å¿pirit is Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿arie and Å¿o great a treaÅ¿ure, let vs that are true ChriÅ¿tians moÅ¿t duetifully thanke our heauenly Father, for beÅ¿towing of him vpon his whole familie here in earth, and vpon euery one of vs that are his Å¿eruants, wherby we are knowen in the worlde, and among our Å¿elues, that wee are his owne. And let vs alÅ¿o pray vnto our Lorde IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, the Å¿ender of this holy Å¿pirit, to kindle and Å¿tirre him vp in our heartes dayly more and more, that by his aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, we may haue an earneÅ¿t feeling and lothing of our Å¿innes, and Å¿o bee brought to doe his will and pleaÅ¿ure, with a carefull keeping of all his commaundements, vntill we all come to a full perfection in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, euen vnto that hope which is layde vp for vs in the newe and heauenly IeruÅ¿alem, which ChriÅ¿t hath purchaÅ¿ed full dearely for vs, with his owne precious heart blood. To
whom with his Father, and the holy ghoÅ¿t, three perÅ¿ons in trinitie, and yet one God in vnitie, be rendred all prayÅ¿e, honour, glorie and thankes giuing, both nowe and for euermore, Amen.

div.head: The ninth Lecture vpon the ninth Article of our ChriÅ¿tian fayth:
The holy catholike Church, the communion of Saints.
div.p:
WE haue declared alreadie vnto you, three parts of this our ChriÅ¿tian fayth: the fyrÅ¿t, wherein we doe beleeue and confeÅ¿Å¿e the Father to bee the Creator and maker of all things: the Å¿econde part, wherein we acknowledge the Sonne IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t the redeemer of mankinde: the thirde Å¿heweth vnto vs the holy GhoÅ¿t, the comforter of our heartes, and the confirmer of all theÅ¿e things which are conteyned in theÅ¿e former eyght articles, which we haue proued all out of the euerlaÅ¿ting worde of GOD.
Nowe followeth conÅ¿equently the fourth part of our ChriÅ¿tian beliefe, which is concerning the Church, the ninth article with other three which are annexed vnto the Church, as the eÅ¿peciall bleÅ¿Å¿ings and benefites which flowe and iÅ¿Å¿ue out of the former partes, and alwayes doe accompanie and followe the Å¿pouÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿t. The cauÅ¿es and matter of our Å¿aluation being alreadie handled, the effect doeth followe, which is the Church: OtherwiÅ¿e in vayne Å¿houlde God create, and ChriÅ¿t redeeme, and the holy GhoÅ¿t inÅ¿pire and confirme theÅ¿e benefites and giftes, vnleÅ¿Å¿e there were Å¿ome that myght bee partakers of thoÅ¿e treaÅ¿ures, brought out and founded by the bleÅ¿Å¿ed Trinitie. Againe, Å¿eeing the kingdome of ChriÅ¿t is euerlaÅ¿ting, it is very neceÅ¿Å¿arie and requiÅ¿ite, that there be alwayes Å¿ome which may acknowledge him for their King and gouernour. To this ende hath ChriÅ¿t his continuall Church, and Å¿hall haue to the ende of the worlde, as he hath had euer from the firÅ¿t beginning. The meaning therefore of this article, is this: I beleeue that God almightie hath alwayes had from the firÅ¿t creation of the
worlde, and hath preÅ¿ently, and Å¿hall haue vnto the conÅ¿ummation of the worlde, his Church here in earth, which is, the coÌmunion of Saints, that is to Å¿ay, a company and congregation of faythfull men and women, which doe truely beleeue in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, acknowledging him for their onely Sauiour, and Å¿eruing him according to his worde, receyuing his Sacraments, and taking holde of all his mercies and benefites by fayth onely in his blood: and for this cauÅ¿e doe wee beleeue that there is but one true Catholique Church, and no moe which Å¿hall continue for euer, although Satan and his miniÅ¿ters goe about by all meanes poÅ¿Å¿ible to ouerthrowe and Å¿ubuert it. Wee are then taught here to beleeue, that there is an vniuerÅ¿all Church of ChriÅ¿t, and not to beleeue and truÅ¿t in it, as we doe in God: for that were idolatrie, to truÅ¿t in men and put our confideÌce in them. But wee muÅ¿t truÅ¿t in GOD onely, and not in this Church, as the PapiÅ¿tes woulde beare vs in hande: becauÅ¿e the Church is but the company of the elect and choÅ¿en, and are men. Nowe wee can not beleeue and put our hope in any thing
that is a creature, for that were blaÅ¿phemie to Å¿ay, and wee are alÅ¿o accurÅ¿ed if wee do Å¿o, as the holy Prophete Ieremie hath by the mouth of the holy GhoÅ¿t forewarned vs, Å¿aying, Thus Å¿ayth the Lorde, CurÅ¿ed bee the man that truÅ¿teth in man, and maketh fleÅ¿h his arme, and withdraweth his heart from the Lorde: for hee Å¿hall be like the heath in the wildernes, and Å¿hall not Å¿ee when any good commeth, but Å¿hall inhabite the parched places in the wilderneÅ¿Å¿e, in a Å¿alte lande and not inhabited, Ier. 17. By theÅ¿e woordes then of the holy ghoÅ¿t, we learne, not to beleeue in ye Church, but that there is an holy Church of ChriÅ¿te in this worlde euery where diÅ¿perÅ¿ed and Å¿cattered abroad through the face of ye whole earth. This article doeth declare vnto vs what the Church is, terming it the communion of Saintes, or fellowÅ¿hippe of the godly, eyther with ChriÅ¿t, or els with themÅ¿elues in loue: furthermore what maner of Church this is, is here likewiÅ¿e Å¿et downe, that it is holy, by reaÅ¿on of ChriÅ¿t her head: & catholike, becauÅ¿e it is not tied to any one place, as Rome, but generally is in all places of the earth, toÅ¿Å¿ed as a Å¿hip vpon the Å¿ea froÌ one coaÅ¿t to another, as pleaÅ¿eth God
to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of it. To theÅ¿e things, two other pointes may be adioyned, to make vp the perfit diÅ¿courÅ¿e of it, and to the which all other thinges incident to any maner queÅ¿tion of the Church, may bee eaÅ¿ely referred. The one is, to conÅ¿ider who is the vniuerÅ¿all head and gouernour of this catholique Church: the other, by what true markes, notes, Å¿ignes, and titles, this Church may be knowen, and diÅ¿cerned from the falÅ¿e and counter faite Å¿ynagogue of Satan, that is, from the whoriÅ¿he and Babylonicall Å¿trumpet of Rome, which falÅ¿ly taketh vpon her the name of this chaÅ¿te wife and Å¿pouÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿te, being an vncleane and a moÅ¿t adulterous harlot, which hath long agoe forÅ¿aken her bridegrome IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, as it Å¿hall (God willing) hereafter better appeare, in the diÅ¿courÅ¿e and tract of this matter. Seeing the Church is likened to an houÅ¿e, 1. Timothie 3. and euery houÅ¿e is builded and gouerned of Å¿ome man, Hebr. 3. it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie that this houÅ¿e alÅ¿o, which is the Church of the liuing God, haue Å¿ome builder & head of it to looke vnto it, which is both able to do it, & moÅ¿t ready to helpe it. The builder of this Chruch is IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, Mat. 16. 18. & he is the only head
of it, as S. Paul doth proue moÅ¿t manifeÅ¿tly vnto vs, both in the 1. & 4. chap. of ye epiÅ¿tle of the EpheÅ¿ians, and the 1. chapter to the ColoÅ¿. Å¿aying, God hath made all thinges Å¿ubiect vnder his feet, and hath giuen him ouer al thinges to be ye head to the Church, which is his body, euen the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of him that filleth all in al things. And againe, Let vs folow the trueth in loue, and in al things growe vp vnto him, which is the head, that is ChriÅ¿t, by whom all the body being coupled and knit together by euery ioynt, for the furniture thereof, according to the effectuall power which is in the meaÅ¿ure of euery part, receyueth increaÅ¿e of the body vnto ye edifiyng of it Å¿elfe in loue, Ephe. 4. So in the ColoÅ¿. 1. 18. He is the head of the body of the Church. Out of this doeth the body of ChriÅ¿t which is his Church, receyue a Å¿pecial and Å¿inguler comfort againÅ¿t al teÌtations, yt they Å¿halbe defended & preÅ¿erued for euer: for ChriÅ¿t caÌ not forÅ¿ake his body, he caÌ not but loue it, & nouriÅ¿h it, wt thoÅ¿e Å¿piritual graces which come & proceede froÌ him ye head & fountaine. For as we Å¿ee in the body naturall, how yt the head receiueth not meate for it Å¿elfe, but for the cheriÅ¿hing and increaÅ¿ing of the Å¿trength of the body, and
the reÅ¿t of the members: Å¿o the Lorde IeÅ¿us is not an head for himÅ¿elf, but for vs, neyther hath hee receyued all power and authoritie of his father, with the fulneÅ¿Å¿e of the holy GhoÅ¿t, to keepe it to him Å¿elfe, but to giue and to impart it moÅ¿t louingly and liberally to his true members, to make them to grow vp more and more, till they come to a perfection in him. If ChriÅ¿t therefore haue Å¿trength, holineÅ¿Å¿e, power, and all other good giftes and graces of the Å¿pirite, then may the Church aÅ¿Å¿ure her Å¿elfe of them all, becauÅ¿e the wife may recken that all the goodes and landes of her huÅ¿bande are hers: and wee knowe that the Church hath this dignitie and prerogatiue, which is ineÅ¿timable and full of wonderfull loue, that Å¿hee is counted and called, as Å¿hee is in very deede, the chaÅ¿te wife and Å¿pouÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿te here vpon the earth, to whome hee is ioyned with the coniunction and fellowÅ¿hippe of his heauenly Å¿pirite. I haue (Å¿ayth Paul) prepared you for one huÅ¿band, to preÅ¿ent you as a pure virgin vnto ChriÅ¿t, 2. Corin. 11. Cantic. 4. Ezechiel 16. EpheÅ¿ians 5. What noble man will bee content to take a poore wretched beggerwoman out of the Å¿treetes, full of ragges and filthineÅ¿Å¿e,
to make her his wife? And yet the Lorde IeÅ¿us hath done greater thinges in mercie for vs, then this: for when hee paÅ¿Å¿ed by, hee looked vpon vs, and beholde, our tyme was as the time of loue, hee Å¿predde his Å¿kirtes ouer vs and couered our filthineÅ¿Å¿e, yea, hee Å¿ware vnto vs, and entred into couenant with vs, and we became his owne. So is the Lorde in mariage become nowe our head, and wee his Å¿pouÅ¿e: let vs then take heede that wee admitte no others into his loue, or defile our Å¿elues with whoredome and idolatrie, in giuing our faith and allegeance to Å¿traungers and falÅ¿e goddes, whome wee knowe not. Our huÅ¿bande is very ielous ouer vs: hee can not abide another man to bee admitted vnto his bedde, for that were Å¿pirituall fornication and adulterie before him, which hee wyll puniÅ¿he moÅ¿t Å¿euerely, as hee did in the IÅ¿raelites which brake couenant with him, and betooke them Å¿elues to Idoles, and bowed downe to them in Å¿teade of him, as the Prophete declareth, Ezechiel 16. Seeyng then ChriÅ¿t is appoynted the head of his Church, and that one wife (as there is but one bodie, which is the Church) can haue but one huÅ¿bande to bee her head,
and one houÅ¿e, but one Lorde and maÅ¿ter to rule it: what wickedneÅ¿Å¿e is it to Å¿ay that the Pope of Rome is an vniuerÅ¿all head ouer the Church? Is not this to take away ChriÅ¿tes roome and dignitie, or rather is it not to make the Church a monÅ¿ter to haue two heades in one body? But they Å¿ay that the ByÅ¿hope of Rome is the viÅ¿ible heade in ChriÅ¿tes Å¿teade: but this they can not Å¿hewe by Scripture, neither doeth the Church require any Å¿uch heade: for ChriÅ¿t is preÅ¿ent with it, as he hath promiÅ¿ed, Mat. 28. I am with you alwayes, euen vnto the ende of the worlde. If the Pope be a viÅ¿ible heade, why is he not Å¿eene of al men? why doeth he not gouerne all men in the Church, and giue nouriÅ¿hment vnto them, as the heade ought to doe? This he doth not: wherefore he is no viÅ¿ible heade, as he doth pretende. And Å¿urely to be the general head ouer al, is too great a matter & enterpriÅ¿e for any mortal man to take vpoÌ him. I am Å¿ure the Pope will graunt him Å¿elfe to be a member of this Catholike Church: If hee then bee a member, howe can hee be an head, except the Å¿ame thing Å¿halbe both an heade and member, which is very abÅ¿urde & monÅ¿truous? If he Å¿ay, that as he is a member,
ChriÅ¿t is his head only, and not another: why Å¿hall not ChriÅ¿t bee as well a head for all? TheÅ¿e thinges (wee Å¿ee) are very childiÅ¿h and fonde. But yet they apply and Å¿ay, that ChriÅ¿t Å¿ayde to Peter, Thou art Peter, and vpon this rocke will I builde my Church. FirÅ¿t note, hee Å¿ayth not vpon thee Peter will I builde, but vpon this rocke, meaning, the fayth of Peters confeÅ¿Å¿ion, which confeÅ¿Å¿ed him to be ChriÅ¿t: therefore by the rocke hee meant himÅ¿elfe. For when Peter had Å¿ayd, Thou art ChriÅ¿t the Å¿onne of God, ChriÅ¿t Å¿ayd to him, Vpon this rocke will I builde my Church: and in that place hee giueth no more to Peter in the keys, which is the binding and loÅ¿ing of Å¿inners, then he giueth to theÌ al els where, as in Ioh. 20. when he Å¿aid, Receiue the holy GhoÅ¿t: whoÅ¿oeuers Å¿innes ye remit, they are remitted, & whoÅ¿oeuers Å¿innes ye reteyne, they are reteyned. Here all haue as much as Peter: and if they will beleeue the fathers, which they brag of much, they do neuer referre this vnto Peter alone, but to the reÅ¿t of ye apoÅ¿tles & to al faithful miniÅ¿ters of IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t. As OrigeÌ in his 1. homi. vpoÌ Mat. & Å¿o doth Cyprian, AmbroÅ¿e, Ierome, & AuguÅ¿tine. And what hath ye pope to do wt
theÅ¿e woordes, which followeth not Peter, neyther in life nor doctrine? A Å¿trange thing it is to Å¿ee, how they builde their kingdome vpon Peter, and whatÅ¿oeuer is Å¿aide of him, they take it to them Å¿elues. But before they can prooue any thing in deede, they muÅ¿t prooue theÅ¿e three poyntes vnto vs, if they wil haue the Pope to be the Å¿upreme head of the whole Church, which they Å¿hall be neuer able to doe by the Å¿criptures, as long as they liue. FirÅ¿t, they muÅ¿t prooue yt Peter was chiefe and head of all the ApoÅ¿tles. Secondly, that he was at Rome, and Å¿ate there as BiÅ¿hop generall. The Å¿umme of all that we haue Å¿aid hitherto, is thus much: that there is an holy church, whoÅ¿e head is IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t alone, to this end and purpoÅ¿e called

And yet for all this, wee here in earth can Å¿atiÅ¿fy our Å¿elues, and be contented to Å¿et foorth his praiÅ¿e, either neuer a whit, or els Å¿o negligently and by Å¿uch Å¿tartes, as wee declare, wee haue no great loue and care thereunto: Å¿o colde is our zeale in this poynt, and yet moÅ¿t hot in trifles and vanites, apperteining to our pleaÅ¿ures & profits in this life. Wee haue nowe heard (dearely beloued) the meaning of this article, concerning the Catholike Church, what it is, and who is the head of it, what authoritye it hath, by what Å¿ignes it may bee alwayes knoweÌ from the RomiÅ¿h or falÅ¿e Church. Now let vs giue thankes to IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, the head of this Church, in that hee hath vouchÅ¿afed to make vs the holy members of it, which were before the firebrandes of hell, and a generation of Satans broode. Seeing then ye the firÅ¿t entrance into the houÅ¿e of the Lord, is by putting away of all our Å¿innes, and becauÅ¿e we haue nothing to do with God, except our offences be blotted and wiped out of his remembraÌce: Let vs a litle I pray you, (dearely beloued brethreÌ in ChriÅ¿t) marke what we haue to coÌÅ¿ider in this article for our inÅ¿tructioÌ & edificatioÌ vnto a godly life.

For if we Å¿ay and graunt a remiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿innes, wee muÅ¿t alÅ¿o confeÅ¿Å¿e that wee are Å¿inners, otherwiÅ¿e wee can not at all haue pardon of them. Secondly we muÅ¿t coÌÅ¿ider by whom this remiÅ¿Å¿ion doeth come vnto vs, and for whoÅ¿e Å¿ake it is. Thirdly by what meanes we are made capable and partakers of this Å¿o great a benefite. div.head: The eleuenth article of our ChriÅ¿tian faith, and the eleuenth lecture vpon it, which is, The reÅ¿urrection of the body.
div.p:
IN the fourth part of this our ChriÅ¿tian beliefe, which was of the church, I declared that there were three conÅ¿equents or benefites annexed vnto it. The firÅ¿t you haue heard, which was the remiÅ¿Å¿ion of Å¿innes: Now doth enÅ¿ue ye Å¿econd, which is the reÅ¿urrection, or riÅ¿ing againe of our fleÅ¿h and bodie. And this article doeth folowe in very good and apt order after the former: for as by the firÅ¿t Adams Å¿inne and ours, our bodies became mortall & Å¿ubiect vnto death: Å¿o hauing remiÅ¿Å¿ion of our Å¿innes by ChriÅ¿t the Å¿econd Adam, our bodies Å¿hal hereafter be made immortall, & raiÅ¿ed from death to an euerlaÅ¿ting & better life theÌ that, which we Å¿hould haue had in ParadiÅ¿e, if Adam & we had coÌtinued in our Å¿tate of innocency. The meaning therefore of this article is thus much: I that am a ChriÅ¿tian, do moÅ¿t certainely beleeue, that not only my body, but the bodyes of all men, that euer haue bene from the beginning of the world to the end of it, Å¿hall at the laÅ¿t day of iudgement, by the power of ChriÅ¿t at his comming, be rayÅ¿ed vp againe, (being the Å¿ame in Å¿ubÅ¿tance, but not in qualities) whether they be rotted in the graue, or burnt in the flaming fire, or conÅ¿umed of beaÅ¿tes, or drowned in the Å¿ea, & deuoured of fiÅ¿hes, or els of birds. And I moreouer beleeue, that they Å¿halbe ioyned to their Å¿oules inÅ¿eperably, at the which reÅ¿urrection the godly Å¿hall haue a full ende of all their miÅ¿eries, and paynes here; with full poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of eternall life, and that the wicked and reprobate Å¿hall goe into euerlaÅ¿ting hel fire, which is prepared for the deuil and his angels. This is the true Å¿enÅ¿e and meaning of this article of the reÅ¿urrection. Now let vs Å¿ee what good leÅ¿Å¿ons may be gathered out of it, for our inÅ¿truction, that wee may the better profite in the way of true godlineÅ¿Å¿e, and ChriÅ¿tianity. one day be a generall reÅ¿urrection of good and bad. Secondly, to what ende this Å¿halbe. Thirdly, the conÅ¿olation and comfort, that wee may reape and inioy by this reÅ¿urrection, in the applying of it to our owne conÅ¿ciences. I am not ignorant, howe that very many thinges muÅ¿t be repeated here, which haue bene Å¿poken of before, both in the article of ChriÅ¿tes reÅ¿urrection, which is a playne confirmation and proofe of this, and alÅ¿o in the other artice of his coÌming agayne to iudgement, which Å¿halbe then when this article Å¿halbe fully accompliÅ¿hed vnto vs. TheÅ¿e thinges are Å¿o incident the one to the other, I meane ChriÅ¿tes reÅ¿urrectioÌ, and his iudgment and our riÅ¿ing againe, that they cannot â¢ e Å¿eparated: howbeit, we will by Gods grace Å¿o Å¿peake of them all, as they Å¿hall tend to godly edification, and to the great comfort of all them that do nowe in theÅ¿e laÅ¿t and dangerous dayes mourne in Zion. And albeit Å¿ome places and reaÅ¿ons Å¿halbe nowe brought here, in ye proofe of this article which haue ben alleaged before: yet it Å¿hall not be amiÅ¿Å¿e to beare them againe and often, that wee may the better remember them, becauÅ¿e
wee are all dull in hearing, and forgetfull of good thinges, Å¿o fickle is our memorie. In the Scriptures both in the Lawe and in the Prophetes, and alÅ¿o in the newe TeÅ¿tament, yee haue the Å¿ame leÅ¿Å¿ons giuen foorth often vnto you, eÅ¿pecially in the PÅ¿almes, where the latter part of the verÅ¿e, is either but a repetition, or els a more playne declaration of the former part of the Å¿entence. Yea, Saint Paul him Å¿elfe well vnderÅ¿toode this to bee a very profitable and good thing, to heare one leÅ¿Å¿on many tymes, and therefore Å¿ayde to the Philippians, It grieueth mee not to wryte the Å¿ame thinges to you, and for you it is a Å¿ure thing, chapter 3. Seeing this is Å¿o, let vs then come to our purpoÅ¿e, which is to proue that there Å¿hall bee a generall reÅ¿urrection of all men. This article is (I graunt) very harde to bee beleeued, if wee iudge of it by fleÅ¿h & blood only, as farre as naturall reaÅ¿on will extende, but where fayth is planted, there reaÅ¿on hath no place. And all the woorkes of God, if they did not paÅ¿Å¿e our reaÅ¿on and capacitie,
then they were there not Å¿o wonderfull, neither Å¿hould theybe vnÅ¿earcheable or paÅ¿t finding out, which S. Paul the ApoÅ¿tle affirmeth, Romanes. 11. Å¿aying, O the deepeneÅ¿Å¿e of the riches, both of the wiÅ¿edome and knowledge of God! Many of the better Å¿ort of the heathen PhiloÅ¿ophers, as Plato, AriÅ¿totle and Cicero, although they were fully perÅ¿waded of ye immortality of ye Å¿oule, yet they neuer did Å¿o much as once dreame or thinke of the immortalitie, and reÅ¿urrection of the fleÅ¿he, which we beare about with vs. So incredible a thing did it Å¿eeme vnto them. And therefore Saint Paul, when hee came to Athens, and there preached ChriÅ¿t IeÅ¿us vnto them, and many other good poyntes of ChriÅ¿tianitye, & of our fayth, they heard him indifferently without any mocking at al: but when he Å¿ayde and affirmed conÅ¿tantly vnto them, that God had appoynted a day, in ye which he wil iudge the worlde in righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, by that man whom hee hath appoynted, wherof he hath giuen an aÅ¿Å¿urance to all men, in that he hath rayÅ¿ed him from the dead, theÌ they mocked, becauÅ¿e they heard of ye reÅ¿urrection from the dead, Actes 17.
Well, notwithÅ¿tanding al this, we that are ChriÅ¿tians and trayned vp in the Å¿chole of ChriÅ¿t our maÅ¿ter, muÅ¿t beleeue this point. For Å¿urely the ful perÅ¿waÅ¿ion of this one article, comprehendeth many other articles of our fayth: For if wee riÅ¿e not agayne, then is not ChriÅ¿t riÅ¿en: if ChriÅ¿t be not riÅ¿en, then are we in our Å¿innes, and Å¿o the former article that went before, falleth to the ground. Let vs therefore heare, and marke alÅ¿o Å¿ome infallible teÅ¿timonies, and authorityes of the euerlaÅ¿ting & true word of God, to builde our fayth vpoÌ in this Å¿o hard & Å¿trange a matter to reaÅ¿on, & to confirme vs againÅ¿t all tentations of Satan, or of the wicked and carnal AtheiÅ¿ts, which wil goe about to vndermine the veritie of this article. We haue in the third chapter of the booke Exodus, a manifeÅ¿t proofe of the reÅ¿urrection in theÅ¿e woordes, where as God Å¿peaking to MoÅ¿es, Å¿ayeth on this wiÅ¿e, I am the God of Abraham, the God of IÅ¿ahac, and the God of Iacob. Which woordes are Å¿o forcible, that our Å¿auiour ChriÅ¿t vÅ¿ed no other argument agaynÅ¿t the
Sadduces which denied this reÅ¿urrection. For God cannot be Å¿ayde to be God of Abraham, except he raiÅ¿e him againe, and the bodye be ioyned to the Å¿oule. For he calleth not himÅ¿elfe, the God of Abrahams Å¿oule, but of Abraham, meaning the whole man. It was euident therefore that Abraham with ye reÅ¿t of ye fathers, Å¿hal riÅ¿e againe. Very excellent is ye place of Iob, in the nineteenth chapter of his booke. I knowe (Å¿ayeth he) that my redeemer liueth, and he Å¿hal Å¿tand the laÅ¿t on the earth, and though after this skinne wormes Å¿hall deuoure this body, yet Å¿hall I Å¿ee God in my fleÅ¿h, whom I my Å¿elfe Å¿hall Å¿ee, & my eyes Å¿hall behold, and none other for me, though my reines are conÅ¿umed with in me. We Å¿ee by this, that Iob long before vs, or before the newe TeÅ¿tament was written, had a full hope of the reÅ¿urrection, that both body and Å¿oule Å¿hould enioy the preÅ¿ence of God at the laÅ¿t day. this is written (as Paul Å¿ayeth) for our inÅ¿truction, that wee Å¿houlde haue the like hope and aÅ¿Å¿urance as hee had, in the happie and bleÅ¿Å¿ed reÅ¿urrection of our bodyes after death. This truÅ¿t and fayth had the Prophet Dauid, in the Å¿ixteenth
pÅ¿alme, Thou Å¿halt not leaue my body in ye graue, neither Å¿halt thou Å¿uffer thy holy one to Å¿ee corruptioÌ. In ye Å¿ix and twentieth of EÅ¿ay we read thus, Thy dead men Å¿hall liue, euen with my body Å¿hall they riÅ¿e. This is then the happines of the bodie: Now howe great Å¿hall the bleÅ¿Å¿edneÅ¿Å¿e be, when both the body and Å¿oule Å¿halbe conioyned together, and raigne for euermoreâª Surely as great as ye glory of the Lorde is, & his excellent MaieÅ¿tie, which is infinite:

Nowe for the comming to this Supper, that wee deceiue not our Å¿elues, we muÅ¿t haue theÅ¿e two things: firÅ¿t, repentance of our former Å¿infull life, to bee Å¿orie for it which is done, by trying and examining our Å¿elues, whether wee bee heartily Å¿orowfull or no for our offences: Å¿econdly, we muÅ¿t haue faith in IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, yt yet we deÅ¿paire not for our great Å¿innes, but truÅ¿t to haue mercy at his handes when we cal vpon him, Å¿o that before we come vnto this banket, wee muÅ¿t prepare our Å¿elues to come worthily, reuerently, in faith, hope, and loue: this is the examination. div.p: I beleeue that the Å¿ame man was ordeined of the Lord God, a maÅ¿ter & ruler ouer all his creatures: the which thing he hath loÅ¿t through his Å¿inne, aÅ¿well for his owne part as alÅ¿o for al his poÅ¿teritie. div.p: I beleeue yt this diÅ¿order and corruption of nature was not only in Adam, becauÅ¿e of his Å¿inne, but is alÅ¿o in all men generally which come of him, (IeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t only excepted) and that in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that all men after their own nature are corrupt, vniuÅ¿t, lyers, ignorant, vnkind, and imperfect in al things, & haue no power of their owne nature to do, thinke, Å¿peake, or will any thing yt may pleaÅ¿e God, vntil yt they be regenerate, & renewed by the Å¿pirit of the Lord.

div.p:

div.head: The xxxix. Article.
